title: How to Make Vanilla French Macarons

steps.headline: Grind 140 grams of almond flour until it becomes fine.
steps.description: To do this place the flour in a food processor or blender. Sift together with 130 grams (4.6 oz) of powdered sugar and place into a large bowl.

steps.headline: Grind 130 grams of granulated sugar until it becomes fine.
steps.description: To do this place the granulated sugar in a food processor or blender. Add the fine granulated sugar to a small saucepan with 5 tablespoons (73.9 ml) of water. Place the saucepan with the granulated sugar on the stovetop. Set heat to medium-high and bring to a constant boil. Let boil for 2-3 minutes to create a simple syrup.

steps.headline: In a large bowl, crack four large eggs.
steps.description: Remove the four egg yolks, leaving just the whites inside the bowl.

steps.headline: Add a pinch of salt to your egg whites.
steps.description: Beat with an electric mixer on a low setting. Take the simple syrup and slowly pour onto the side of the bowl, incorporating the simple syrup into the egg whites. While slowly increasing speed, beat the mixture until it forms glossy, stiff peaks. Add a teaspoon of lemon juice and vanilla halfway through mixing to help stabilize the egg whites. Add some optional food coloring halfway through of your choice until the desired color is reached.

steps.headline: Scoop the egg whites on top of the mixture and start to fold.
steps.description: In the large bowl with the almond flour and powdered sugar mixture, scoop the egg whites on top of the mixture and fold the mixture until it is completely incorporated. The mixture should be fully incorporated when you can make a figure 8 with the mixture without it breaking in the bowl. Once this consistency has been achieved, do not mix any further.

steps.headline: Scoop your mixture into a piping bag.
steps.description: If you do not have a piping bag, you can easily make one out of a zip lock bag by cutting a small piece of the corner, then fitting with an icing tip. Make sure you have a regular icing tip that can create circles.

steps.headline: Grab a cookie sheet and line with parchment paper.
steps.description: Begin to pipe your mixture with around 12-15 circles that are about an inch and half in diameter.

steps.headline: Remove any air bubbles that are trapped within the macaron batter.
steps.description: To accomplish this, drop the cookie sheet onto a flat service a couple of inches high 5 to 10 times until there are no air bubbles present.

steps.headline: Wait for the macarons to set.
steps.description: Wait 30 minutes to an hour for the macarons to set once they have formed a thin layer of skin across the top. To test if they are properly set, run your fingers across the top. If it is smooth to the touch and no batter is present on your finger, they are ready to be baked.

steps.headline: Preheat oven at 300 °F (149 °C) and bake for 12-15 minutes.
steps.description: Check your macarons half-way through cooking and allow to cool completely before removing from the baking sheet.

steps.headline: Grab a room temperature stick of butter and place into a large bowl.
steps.description: Using a stand or hand mixer, cream together with 1 tablespoon (14.8 ml) of vanilla and a pinch of salt.

steps.headline: Slowly add 4 cups of powdered sugar to the mixture, increasing the speed of the mixer.
steps.description: About halfway through, add 1 to 3 tablespoons (14.8 to 44.4 ml) of almond milk to the mixture. This will help with the thickness of the buttercream, allowing it to become even and smooth. Once the mixture looks and feels velvet smooth, begin to fold optional sprinkles into the mixture until they're covered and combined.

steps.headline: Once completely cool, take your macarons off the sheet.
steps.description: The macarons should easily lift off of the baking sheet if they are properly cooled.

steps.headline: Pipe buttercream on the flat side of one macaron.
steps.description: Place another macaron on top creating a sandwich. Repeat until there are no remaining macaron shells.

steps.headline: Place your macarons in a container.
steps.description: Refrigerate at least 24 hours before serving to allow the macarons to properly rest.

Take the simple syrup and slowly pour onto the side of the bowl, incorporating the simple syrup into the egg whites. While slowly increasing speed, beat the mixture until it forms glossy, stiff peaks. Add a teaspoon of lemon juice and vanilla halfway through mixing to help stabilize the egg whites. Add some optional food coloring halfway through of your choice until the desired color is reached. Scoop the egg whites on top of the mixture and start to fold. The mixture should be fully incorporated when you can make a figure 8 with the mixture without it breaking in the bowl. Once this consistency has been achieved, do not mix any further. Scoop your mixture into a piping bag. If you do not have a piping bag, you can easily make one out of a zip lock bag by cutting a small piece of the corner, then fitting with an icing tip. Make sure you have a regular icing tip that can create circles. Grab a cookie sheet and line with parchment paper. Begin to pipe your mixture with around 12-15 circles that are about an inch and half in diameter. Remove any air bubbles that are trapped within the macaron batter. To accomplish this, drop the cookie sheet onto a flat service a couple of inches high 5 to 10 times until there are no air bubbles present. Wait for the macarons to set. Wait 30 minutes to an hour for the macarons to set once they have formed a thin layer of skin across the top. To test if they are properly set, run your fingers across the top. If it is smooth to the touch and no batter is present on your finger, they are ready to be baked. Preheat oven at 300 °F (149 °C) and bake for 12-15 minutes. Check your macarons half-way through cooking and allow to cool completely before removing from the baking sheet. Making the Buttercream Grab a room temperature stick of butter and place into a large bowl. Using a stand or hand mixer, cream together with 1 tablespoon (14.8 ml) of vanilla and a pinch of salt. Slowly add 4 cups of powdered sugar to the mixture, increasing the speed of the mixer. About halfway through, add 1 to 3 tablespoons (14.8 to 44.4 ml) of almond milk to the mixture. This will help with the thickness of the buttercream, allowing it to become even and smooth. Once the mixture looks and feels velvet smooth, begin to fold optional sprinkles into the mixture until they're covered and combined. Pipe buttercream on the flat side of one macaron. Place another macaron on top creating a sandwich. Repeat until there are no remaining macaron shells. Place your macarons in a container. Refrigerate at least 24 hours before serving to allow the macarons to properly rest.
